Revision – Indirect Speech

Let's revise some examples from Lesson 2.
I learn German because I want to learn German – Ich lerne Deutsch weil ich Deutsch lernen will.
He plays tennis even though he wants to play cricket – Er spielt Tennis obwohl er Cricket spielen will.
I think we should eat pizza – Ich denke dass wir Pizza essen sollen.
I want to ask if Ankit is in Munich – Ich will fragen ob Ankit in München ist.
I want to know where Ankita is – Ich will wissen wo Ankita ist.

Comparative Degrees

In German, adjectives change for comparisons in a special way.
In English: cheap → cheaper → cheapest.
In German: billig → billiger → am billigsten.
Formula:
Comparative: adjective + er (billig → billiger)
Superlative: am + adjective + sten (billig → am billigsten).

Comparatives in Sentences

How to use them in sentences:
1. 'As ... as' → so ... wie
Coke is as cheap as Pepsi → Coke ist so billig wie Pepsi.

2. 'Comparative ... than' → comparative + als
Coke is cheaper than Pepsi → Coke ist billiger als Pepsi.

3. Superlative → am + adjective + sten
Coke is cheapest → Coke ist am billigsten.

More Examples

Tea is as tasty as coffee → Tee ist so lecker wie Kaffee.
Tea is tastier than coffee → Tee ist leckerer als Kaffee.
Tea is tastiest → Tee ist am leckersten.

Irregular Comparatives

Just like in English (good → better → best), some German adjectives don’t follow the normal rules:

  • gut → besser → am besten
  • viel → mehr → am meisten
We will meet more irregular forms as we continue learning.

Summary

Formulas:
Comparative: adjective + er
Superlative: am + adjective + sten
Sentence structures:
– 'As ... as' = so ... wie
– 'Comparative than' = comparative + als
– Superlative = am + adjective + sten
Some adjectives are irregular (gut → besser → am besten).
